Dear Ms. Keller:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 734-395-0920.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12404 Placement
Section (4) An agency shall consider all of the following factors in selecting
Description an appropriate placement for a child:
(b) The physical, emotional, and educational needs of the child.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency was provided a safety alert in September 2022 and
not all of the issues were resolved. The agency moved a youth
based on some unresolved issues and additional issues, leaving 5
youth in an unsafe home.
Investigation This investigation was opened after DCWL analyst follow up with
the agency on a 09/26/22 safety alert brought up concerns related
to the safety of the relative placement.
Documentation reviewed:
Review of the safety alert dated 9/26/22. Safety alert indicates the
relative care providers home had no working smoke detectors or
carbon monoxide detectors, three windows needed repair (glass
and screens were missing), one window was unable to close, (two
children sleep in this room) electrical issues (3 bedrooms have no
working outlets and bathroom lights do not work), the electrical
appears to be a safety issue and sewage was observed in the
basement.
The agency reported on the safety alert, and noted they were able
to resolve the smoke detector and carbon monoxide detector
issue. They were able to repair the three windows that needed
glass and screens. One window was unable to close but they
were able to close it more and placed a thick cloth over the
opening to stop the cold air from coming in. The window required
a custom fix, and they contacted a window company to assist. The
agency purchased battery operated lighting for the bathroom and
bedrooms and contacted an electrician to evaluate and fix the
electrical issue. A plumber was able to clean up and fix the
sewage issue.
Review of the safety alert email updates between the DCWL
Analyst and Wolverine from October 2022-February 2023. On
10/13/22 the Field Analyst requested an update from Wolverine in
regard to resolving the safety alert. Wolverine emailed indicating
2

the home has cockroaches and a bed bug infestation and the
window company and electrician both cancelled and would not
come into the home to complete repairs or do estimates. An
exterminator was hired, and the first extermination treatment was
10/13/22 and the second treatment would be the following week.
Once the second treatment was complete the home should be
fully treated, and the window and electrician could be contacted to
enter the home and complete the necessary work.
DCWL Analyst requested update on 11/28/22. No response was
documented.
January 11, 2023, the DCWL Analyst asked for a safety alert
update. Wolverine’s response email indicated the home continued
to have a bug infestation even after the extermination treatments.
The agency said that the relative care provider is not complying
after multiple meetings and they agency is looking for replacement
homes for the children.
O 2/9/23 the DCWL Analyst requested a safety alert update from
Wolverine. Wolverine email response was that the children were
moving the next day; 2/10/23.
The agency provided a detailed outline of their efforts to assist the
family with the safety alerts/concerns in the home which included
the following:
• August 2022 the agency discovered the bedframes DHHS
provided to the family were broken and unsafe to be used.
The family was instructed to take them down due to safety
concerns and the mattresses were placed on the floor for
each child to sleep on.
• September 2022 the licensing worker discovered a hole in
the stairwell wall, a smoke alarm was needed in the
basement, broken windows in some of the rooms, and the
children's beds were missing. A smoke detector was
installed in the basement at the visit. Standing water was in
the basement from a shower leak. The relative care
provider had thrown away the mattresses indicating they
were dirty, so the children did not have beds. The agency
took air mattresses to the home for all the children. A
safety plan was implemented for the children to sleep in
their assigned room on the air mattresses. It was
discovered on 9/27/22 that the home was infested with
coach roaches. On 9/28/22, a plumber was scheduled to
go to the home and the issues were resolved during that
appointment regarding the standing water in the basement.
3

Windows and screens were replaced in September and
battery-operated lights for the bedroom and bathroom were
provided.
• October 4, 2022, the licensing worker met the exterminator
company for an estimate, and it was discovered the home
also had a bed bug infestation. The window company and
electrician who were scheduled to work in the home
refused to enter the home due to the bug infestations. It
was also discovered that day that the unsafe bunk beds
were still up, and the basement had no electricity. On
10/13/22 the initial treatment for bed bugs and roaches was
completed.
• October 21, 2022, a Family Team Meeting was held with
the relative. Concerns discussed at the Family Team
Meeting were the needed home repairs and the relative
care providers needed to keep up the home, the need for
the relative care provider to have employment/income,
parenting concerns with ensuring the children's medical,
dental, and mental health needs were being met. Medical
appointments were missed and not attended.
• November 14, 2022, the foster care worker met with the
relative care provider and discussed the need for legal
income and adoption documentation that had not been
provided. The relative's adult son who lived in the home
reported the home had been infested with bed bugs and
roaches for nearly 7 years at the visit. The exterminator
treatments were completed on 11/30/22.
• There was a court hearing on 11/14/22 and the Referee
expressed concern with the relative placement’s lack of
care to the children and stated that children have been
removed from the care of birth parents for the same living
conditions and lack of care. Referee strongly recommended
that the agency find a solution to the issues up to and
including removing the children from the relative care
provider.
• On 12/5/22 a Family Team Meeting occurred with the
relative care provider where they discussed the need for
legal income and legal documents for the adoption. At a
home visit on 12/5/22 it was discovered that the air
mattresses provided to the relative were all broken, and the
relative had not reported this which was part of the safety
plan developed around safe sleep. The agency provided
three beds for the family on 12/5/22. A case conference
occurred on 12/21/22 with foster care, adoption, licensing,
GAL, and DHHS and it was agreed the children should be
removed from the relative home.
4

• On 1/6/23 a case conference request was sent to MCI to
seek permission to remove the children. Approval was
provided without a conference to the facility by MCI. MCI
requested they seek a foster home that could take all five
children. On 1/27/23 the agency requested permission to
split the children as they could not locate one foster home
for all five children. MCI approved a sibling split on
1/30/23. On 2/10/23 the relative care provider was given
the DHHS -30 notification of replacement, and the children
were removed and placed in two foster homes. The
agency reported the children were replaced due to the
relative being unwilling to obtain legal income, unwilling to
provide the documents for adoption/provide permanency,
the lack of follow through with the agency for appointments
and the children's appointments, the bug infestation,
inability to fix the window and electrical, on-going bedding
issues for the children.
Interviews:
I interviewed the Foster Care Worker on 3/2/23 via the phone. She
reported that she has been the foster care worker since the
agency accepted the case from the department. The Foster Care
worker reported that she had a pretty good relationship with the
relative in the beginning, but the relationship deteriorated over
time as the relative became less compliant and more combative
with her. The Foster Care Worker reported the first concern she
had was over medicals for the children taking over 4 months to get
completed. The Foster Care Worker reported income was an
issue in the home as the relative care provider did not want to
work. The Foster Care Worker reported the relative care provider
expected the agency to fix all of the issues she had with her
home. The relative was often not forthcoming with the issues in
the home, and new things kept coming up. The Foster Care
worker reported there was a large electricity bill that was unpaid,
the lights in the house were an issue and worked in only some
rooms, the beds were frequently broken, and the children were not
sleeping in their designated rooms. The relative care provider
discarded the beds that were purchased for her and allowed the
children to jump on the beds and air mattresses resulting in them
being broken frequently. The Foster Care Worker reported the
relative became combative with her in June of 2022 as she didn’t
like the Foster Care Worker questioning her about her income,
bills, the beds etc. The Foster Care Worker reported the relative
asked the Foster Care Worker to pay her property taxes and there
was a $2,000 utility bill. The Foster Care Worker reported the
relative did not communicate her needs and issues and she was
5

often finding out the issues after the fact. The Foster Care Worker
reported in September the relative became more unresponsive
and wouldn't answer her phone and became more difficult to work
with. The foster care worker reported the home felt unsafe in
August/September 2022. The foster care worker reported she
brought up her concerns to her supervisor and the supervisors
kept pushing to get resources to help the relative. The Foster Care
Worker reported the relative became most combative in
November after court. The Foster Care Worker reported in
December it was determined the placement was not safe due to
still having bed bugs, cock roaches, the relative not complying
with requests, beds broken again, the air mattresses were broken
again, and the relative was not following the safety plan, had no
income, and continued to have safety issues in the home
(electrical and window).
I interviewed the Adoption Supervisor on 3/28/23 via the phone.
The Adoption Supervisor reported that she was the adoption
worker on the case. She received the case on 8/15/22. The
Adoption Supervisor reported safety concerns at her first home
visit. Those concerns were that the relative slept in the dining
room, that she couldn't go into the basement as there was no
electricity, all the children were sharing one bedroom, she needed
a flashlight to illuminate the upstairs. The Adoption Supervisor
reported there was a constant concern with the children sharing
bedrooms and not following the safety plan. The Adoption
Supervisor reported the agency provided air mattresses 2-3 times
due to them being popped and the family had an on-going bug
infestation. The Adoption Supervisor reported the relative was
asked for adoption paperwork multiple times and only provided a
small amount of the necessary paperwork. The Adoption
Supervisor reported the relative did not have a legal source of
income. The Adoption Supervisor reported she couldn't have
done an adoption in the home due to the poor condition of the
home including spotty electricity, bugs, basement was unsafe with
no electrical, broken windows and standing water in the
basement. The Adoption Supervisor reported the relative care
provider couldn't meet the needs of the children. She reported the
children missed medical appointments and the relative stopped
going to appointments. The adoption supervisor reported she had
concerns with the relative’s parenting skills that the children were
clean but one of the children was not speaking yet and had
language issues, one was not potty trained, and she didn't go to
an intake appointment for one of the children to be assessed. The
Adoption Supervisor reported the children were never in imminent
danger or immediate risk of harm. The Adoption Supervisor
6

reported the children were replaced without notice or visitation
with their new placements due to fear of the relative
leaving/running with the children if provided notification of
replacement. The Adoption Supervisor reported the relative never
threatened to leave with the children, but it was just a fear the
agency had. The children were removed from school and placed
in new foster homes. The Adoption Supervisor reported the
relative did not have an intense reaction and cried, but agreed if
the agency felt it was best for the children. The adoption
supervisor reported the agency was concerned with the relative’s
mental health and that she had a CPS history and was reportedly
suffering from mental health issues, but they never saw any signs
or unusual behavior and the relative did not take medication.
I interviewed the Foster Care Supervisor on 2/9/23 via teams.
The Foster Care Supervisor reported the relative home was clean
and safe, but her care of the children was poor. She went on to
say the initial well child exams took 4 months. The Foster Care
Supervisor reported the relative allowed the children to jump on
the beds and break them. The Foster Care Supervisor reported
that they did written safety plans to address concerns with beds.
The Foster Care Supervisor reported over time the relative
stopped answering the phone and became hard to get a hold of or
work with. The Foster Care Supervisor reported they provided air
mattresses for the children several times.
I interviewed the Child Welfare Director on 2/9/23 via Teams
conference. She reported that CPS did the initial placement with
the relative and it was a struggle with the relative all along. The
Director reported they attempted to work with the relative for
several months as they were concerned that the children had lived
with the relative for most of their lives. The Director indicated it is
really hard to move kids from a relative and they tried really hard
to preserve the placement but the relative would not comply and
new conditions in the home kept coming up. The Director reported
on 12/5/23 they determined the children would need to move from
the relatives home due to the conditions in the home, lack of
permanency, and the relatives lack of doing what she needed to
do to provide for the children. The Director reported the children
were moved without notification due to concerns with the relative’s
mental health. The Director reported the relative had a history with
CPS that alleged she tried to smother one of her own kids. The
Director reported they wanted to make sure the relative was not
going to retaliate in any way with the children. The Director
denied that they had ever had any concerns with the relative’s
7

mental health and have never experienced her displaying unusual
behavior during the case.
Analysis Based upon interviews and a review of documentation there is
evidence to support the physical, emotional, and educational
needs of the children were not being met in the relative
placement. The conditions of the home were a safety concern in
August 2022 and continued to be a safety concern and increase in
severity as the case progressed. The children should have been
removed from the home when it became evident that the relative
was not cooperating, and they could not accomplish the repairs
needed in the home to make it safe. The court expressed concern
with the care for the children and the home conditions and ordered
the agency to resolve the issues and remove the children if
necessary. The children were not moved from the home for
another three months. The children were left in a placement that
was unsafe for several months.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
